spans.content: 2018),and then the source stayed in the hard state for roughly three
months with slowly decreasing luminosity (Shidatsu et al. 2019).
This unusually long and bright hard state makes it an excellent target
to study the rich soft and hard X-ray spectral and timing phenomena
(e.g. Kara et al. 2019; Ma et al. 2020; Stiele & Kong 2020; You
et al.2021).As optical LFQPOs are observed at frequencies nearly
identical to that seen in the X-ray band (Yu et al. 2O18b,a),multi-
wavelength timing observations of theLFQPOs will provide critical
clues to the origin of the LFQPOs as well (Mao et al. 2022).
details of Insight-HXMT can be seen in data reduction guide1. In-
sight-HXMT has performed high cadence monitoring observations
forthis outburst.The broad X-ray energy band and the high count
rate during the hard state observations provide us an opportunity
to explore the energy spectrum evolution on short timescale.In this
work,we use the Insight-HXMT data to explore the broadband
spectral variation within the LFQPO timescale.
We used the observation taken on March 27，2018 (ObsId
P01146610o6),when the flux is near its maximum of the hard state
(Shidatsu et al.2019).The exposure time of this observation is about
Weused the Insight-HXMT data analysis software HXMTDAS
toextract thedata from threepayloads.To avoid contamina-
tion from nearby sources,we chose the narrowFOVs for all three
telescopes.For creating good-time-intervals (GTIs), we used the sug-
gested criteria in the guide.We then generated the energy spectrum
and the corresponding background from the screened event,as well
as the light curve of 8ms resolution.
We grouped the spectra with minimum of 2O counts per bin.The spec-
tral fitting performed by XSPEC version 12.11.1 with Chi statistics.

out taking into account the ionization gradient. The comparison
between thereflkerr and the other popular relativistic reflection
modelrelxill is extensively shown in Dzielak etal. (2019).

during the hard state (Buisson et al. 2019; You et al. 2021). However,

Figure 2 shows the light curves of three instruments with time
similar to that of thedetectedLFQPO.In orderto quantitatively
identify the peak(high intensity)and trough (low intensity) phases of
the flares corresponding to the LFQPO waveform, we used the local
maxima/minima method to select the extreme from the beginning to
the end of the light curve.The method takes a fixed-width window
and moves in order from the light curve without overlapping, picking
theextreme values of the curve in the window with each move.
Since the central frequency of the detected QPO is

of the light curve as two reference flux
